review_title: Great, if you can get hired
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Macomb, MI
pros: Dream job if you are a patient teacher willing to be flexible with your teaching methods. Very flexible; work a little or a lot.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Good culture and work environment.

job_title: Financial Aid Counter Help in Warren, MI
pros: Director is great.  Peers are nice.  Hours are good albeit part-time.  Hourly wages are fair.
cons: Very power hungry department when it comes to middle and low level "supervisors".  Egos run rampant.  Gossip and catty behavior prevail.  It's a very difficult environment to work in.  Team work is non-existent.  The students can be very mean and rude.  And so can some of the staff members.

review_title: Part-time Work Was Enjoyable and Rewarding
pros: Staff and faculty were very helpful and friendly. Part-time scheduling was very flexible, which was great for college students. Managers were kind and eager to help. Departments were able to cooperate easily and the lines of communication were very open.
cons: There seemed to be a block between administration and staff. There was definitely a hierarchy. Little opportunity for upward advancement (especially few full-time opportunities). Students could be highly difficult and there were times public safety had to be called.

review_title: Aging faculty, last minute schedule changes, poor pay
pros: The classrooms have nice technology and parking is decently easy.
cons: Aging faculty who don't really teach (check out the ratings) but they bump you out of your classes. Don't bother preparing for the classes in advance, they get cancelled at the last minute. They want the best credentials but pay even less than equivalency of minimum wage when you take into account all they want you to do and commute times. Don't take a job here unless you are desperate and want to be jerked around by incompetent full timers who really should have retired long ago.

review_title: Average jobs, but poor management and insulting wage for part time employees
job_title: Computer Support Technician in Warren, MI
pros: MCC (Macomb Community College) is a convenient place to work, at either campus, since it's located off of easily accessible highways, and have nice looking campuses.  There is tasty and moderately inexpensive dining on campus (available during the fall and winter semesters), and an abundance of water fountains and bathrooms available.  Many of the people who work for the organization are pleasant, and taking time off isn't often a problem (this may depend on the particular area of coverage).  The colleges are also in close proximity of several fast-food options for lunch, and for a lot of people it's convenient to take classes (extremely affordable classes) at night after working during the day.
cons:
To put it lightly, part-time employee compensation is insulting.  There are several different "levels" of wage for part time employees, which correspond to the job role.  For example, a computer technician may be a level three, while a library clerk may be a level two.  This is mandated by the union that is in place, which despite claims about protecting employees and offering great benefit, have wages for a level three (the top "normal" tier of worker) starting around $10/hr after 90 days, capping out at ~$14 after eight years of service (not including the 2.5% annual increase per pay grade).  This can be contrasted with a level one worker earning a paltry ~$7.75 after their 90 days.  Additionally, the annual raises begin on July 1st, and if you haven't reached your one-year at that date, you'll have to wait until the NEXT July 1st to begin receiving your annual raise.  So, for example, if you were hired in August you won't receive your "annual" raise until you've worked for 23 months.

Benefits are essentially non-existent.  On July 1st of the year if you've come to a full year of service you will begin to accrue time off at 1% of what you work, which given a 30 hour a week maximum, you'll have a little more than two days off.  Of course, just like the pay raises, if your start date was after July 1st, you'll need to wait another year to begin accruing time off.  Over time, this grows to 1.5% for years 3-6 and 2% for 6+.  The only insurance option to buy in to is an offer for 1% off of Metlife.  There are a few discount offers through the union, the best of which is a 15% AT&T contract discount.  There are a multitude of holidays and days off, but for part time workers this isn't a vacation day as much as it's a "don't bother coming in because we're not paying you" day; part time workers do not get any kind of vacation pay for holidays, regardless of whether it's a day like Memorial day, or Christmas.

Management in my department doesn't manage much at all.  There is little, if any leadership, and the opportunity to move up to a full time position is wholly dependent on either someone quitting or dieing, provided that a position isn't eliminated to save on payroll.  Please bear in mind that this may be different based on your department.  The full time positions pay very well (too well, in my opinion) and offer good benefits as far as I can tell, but with financial hardships for the college and a lack of government funding (and an increase in attendance) there is a constant need to save money and eliminate positions.  Additionally, there is a move to make more positions part time, thus saving the college money.  In fact, in a recent "state of the college" address, the president proudly displayed on his Powerpoint presentation that less than ONE THIRD of the employees at the college are full time.  This is ironic, given the fact that many managers and administrators are more than happy to request expensive equipment and room changes, such as unnecessary computer hardware and printers, expensive software, and electrical/network installations.

review_title: Good place to earn entry level tutoring experience
job_title: Foreign Language Tutor in Warren, MI
pros: Give you a chance to get tutoring jobs with no previous experience provided that you know the material very well and can provide a letter of recommendation. Next to no supervision so you can pretty much run the tutoring session as you see fit. Very enjoyable work. Easy to do in addition to another job/school. Looks good on a resume.
cons: Very few hours.  You may only be scheduled one hour a week. You would do this job because you enjoy teaching the material, not because you need it to pay the bills.

review_title: Good benefits, no support from top leadership
pros:
Benefits for full-time employees
Flex and comp time
cons: MCC takes advantage of part-time employees; no benefits, no paid holidays. If the college closes due to bad weather, a PT employee loses a day of pay.  They would rather hire two or three PT employees than one FT employee.  Due to "step" pay system, it takes forever to get a raise, which are based on longevity, not merit.

review_title: Easy, minimal effort job for a serious student
job_title: Computer Lab Aide in Macomb, MI
pros: The position had a lot of down time which I could use to do homework. As a result, it's a great student position to use for studying and completing assignments while earning some money on the side. The faculty and supervisors are generally laid back and understanding.
cons: The amount of downtime to actual work is crazy. If you don't have other things to do, you have to find ways to fill the time.

pros: Flexible schedule, easy-going approach, good supervisors and managers, may be able to cooperate with students who want private tutoring sessions.
cons: Low pay compare to the minimum requirements, most tutor must already have a associate or bachelor to be effective. End of semester drama.

job_title: Part Time Employee in Clinton Township, MI
pros:
- THE STUDENTS! If you're in a position which allows you to work directly with students, you'll LOVE your job. This is my favorite part about what I do
- Learn a lot about people, different cultures, etc. You can get pretty cultured here and meet a ton of people
- Good experience for a job in the future
- Working here will make you appreciate your next job even more
- It's fun to say you work at a College
- Campus Police are AWESOME!!!! They're friendly and do a great job. THANK YOU
- College will pay your tuition for MCC courses IF you work a certain number of hours
- Student Life & Leadership is a great dept
- SOS Dept is INVALUABLE to students. amazing, thank you!
- Food pantry = GREAT
- You'll see a pattern here, if you CARE about people, you'll do a great service to the students, but you'll be unappreciated by the college itself & senior leaders.
cons:
- Huge disconnect between staff/students. MOST of the staff treat the students like dirt
- Many of the employees work in customer-service oriented positions, yet have NO BUSINESS working with people. They're grouchy, cold, and rude. They belong in a cubicle hidden away from the public
- Lack of loyalty to current staff. Will pass up some amazing employees for promotions and then bring in someone from the outside with a fancy degree who has never worked in the local area or at a community college before
- Most positions are part time or adjunct. You struggle to make ends meet and see full-time employees enjoying high salaries, lots of vacation time, paid tuition for masters degrees, etc. It's disheartening & frustrating
- Lots of "office politics" and favorites
- Lots of old people who should have retired a long time ago...
- No staff parking unless you're full time
- You don't get "days off," but you accumulate hours for sick time and vacations based on how much you work, which is limited by the college
- Even though South and Center are both MCC, they feel like completely different worlds. For example, the math or english dept at one campuses teaches differently and uses different textbooks
- You hear a lot of negative experiences from students which is so frustrating
- Time and time again, you'll hear how the counseling/advising dept fails students
- Your hours will be cut during slow times and you'll be worked to the bone during busy times
- You might have a new schedule EVERY single semester

pros: Discount on tuition. Flexible with other work schedule or classes. Reasonable pay and days requested off were mostly honored if within reason.
cons: No possibility for growth since this was a part time position. Management was not organized and was often on vacation.

job_title: Adjunct Design Professor in Warren, MI
pros: The class sizes are small, typically 18–24 students. The semesters are 16 weeks with classes meeting for 3 hours twice a week, plenty of time to cover course work and get to know the students.
cons: There is a huge disparity between full-time pay per class and adjunct pay per class. The system for hiring FT positions is not transparent.
